message: I'm a freelance software developer, no employees. The main benefit, other than limited liability, would be to minimize self employment taxes.
Anyone have any experience/advice regarding S Corps? My accountant says it's time to move away from a sole proprietorship.
For some contracting jobs, especially in IT, clients may require you to Inc. your company.  Similar thinking across North America.
There are also taxation benefits (e.g. smarter accounting with your expenses), however, it requires you to hire a real accountant and/or lawyer

annual legal/filing fees are very minimal for s-corps. If you have any significant income/expenses, you should use an accountant for taxes. S-corps are the way to go in most cases for small businesses - plus s-corp will allow you to have basically zero business liability if you sign contracts using your business name instead of your personal name.
Get an LLC if you're moving from a Sole Proprietorship. Similarly low-hassle but with more protection.
